title-group.article-title: Cytochrome P450 enzymes: A driving force of plant diterpene diversity

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Review
Cytochrome P450 enzymes: A driving force of plant diterpene diversity
Ulschan Bathe, Alain Tissier ∗
Department of Cell and Metabolic Biology, Leibniz Institute of Plant Biochemistry, Weinberg 3, 06120 Halle, Germany
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Plant diterpenoid biosynthesis Cytochrome P450 oxygenases Phylogeny
Evolution
A B S T R A C T

In plant terpene biosynthesis, oxidation of the hydrocarbon backbone produced by terpene synthases is typically carried out by cytochrome P450 oxygenases (CYPs). The modifications introduced by CYPs include hydroxylations, sequential oxidations at one position and ring rearrangements and closures. These reactions significantly expand the structural diversity of terpenoids, but also provide anchoring points for further decorations by various transferases. In recent years, there has been a significant increase in reports of CYPs involved in plant terpene pathways. Plant diterpenes represent an important class of metabolites that includes hormones and a number of industrially relevant compounds such as pharmaceutical, aroma or food ingredients. In this review, we provide a comprehensive survey on CYPs reported to be involved in plant diterpene biosynthesis to date. A phylogenetic analysis showed that only few CYP clans are represented in diterpene biosynthesis, namely CYP 71, CYP 85 and CYP 72. Remarkably few CYP families and subfamilies within those clans are involved, indicating specific expansion of these clades in plant diterpene biosynthesis. Nonetheless, the evolutionary trajectory of CYPs of specialized diterpene biosynthesis is diverse. Some are recently derived from gibberellin biosynthesis, while others have a more ancient history with recent expansions in specific plant families. Among diterpenoids, labdane-related diterpenoids represent a dominant class. The availability of CYPs from diverse plant species able to catalyze oxidations in specific regions of the labdane-related backbones provides opportunities for combinatorial biosynthesis to produce novel diterpene compounds that can be screened for biological activities of interest.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
Terpenoid biosynthesis can be divided into three major steps, each contributing to the structural diversity of this compound class. Terpene synthases ( TPS ) constitute the first step and convert linear isoprenyl diphosphates to linear or cyclic terpene olefins or terpene alcohols. Collectively, TPS generate the diversity of the terpene backbone structures found in Nature. They can catalyze the formation of one major product or of several products in defined relative amounts. Some TPS can accept several isoprenyl diphosphates (e.g. GPP and FPP) while others are specific for one substrate (
). In the next step, terpenes, or terpene alcohols, are typically oxidized at specific positions and in a stereospecific manner. In plants, the vast majority of the terpene oxidations reported so far are carried out by cytochrome P450 oxygenases (CYPs), but some can be brought about by dioxygenases and various types of dehydrogenases. These oxidations can occur sequentially at a given position to give rise to carboxylic acids, but can also lead to rearrangements of the terpene backbone structure, for example by creating novel C-C linkages. Also, some enzymes are able in vitro or in other organisms to oxidize a given backbone at distinct positions or to oxidize related substrates. To what extent this apparent promiscuity is relevant in planta and whether this is a general property of enzymes of specialized metabolism is still unclear. In the final block of reactions, further functionalization of the oxidized terpenoids occurs by the addition of a variety of substituents, including acyl, glycosyl, benzoyl, or even alkaloid groups.

sec.title: 2. Origin of diterpene backbone diversity
3. Overview of plant CYPs involved in diterpene metabolism

3.1. The plant diterpene CYPs constitute a phylogenetically diverse group
but are confined to few CYP families
sec.p:
The limited number of CYP families found among the diterpene CYPs also reflects the occurrence of expansions in specific plant families or taxonomic groups. Thus, the CYP 725 A family is specific to
Taxus sp.
, CYP 720B to resinous conifers, and CYP 726 A to the Euphorbiaceae ( Fig. 2 ). CYP 76s involved in diterpene metabolism are found in both monocots and eudicots, but here sub-families underwent expansion in specific plant taxa, like the CYP 76AH and CYP 76AK from the Lamiaceae . The occurrence of a limited number of CYP families among diterpene CYPs could also be interpreted as a bias due to the still relatively small number of plant families that have been investigated so far with regards to diterpenoid metabolism. It will be interesting to see in the future if this concentration within a reduced set of CYP families is a general trend or if novel families will appear as our knowledge of diterpenoid metabolism in plants expands.

sec.title: 3.2. Substrate specificity and promiscuity of plant CYPs in diterpenoid metabolism
sec.p:
Considering the positions on the diterpene backbone where the oxidation takes place, CYP 720Bs and CYP 76AKs, but also KOs and KAOs from gibberellin biosynthesis, appear to be highly selective since they oxidize their substrate at a single C-position ( Fig. 2 , Table 2 ). With the present knowledge, CYP 99As and CYP 71Zs are also highly selective regarding the oxidized C-position, but the small number of known genes from these subfamilies makes it difficult to reach firm conclusions. In contrast, CYP 76AHs, CYP 76Ms as well as CYP 726As and CYP 71Ds from Euphorbiaceae oxidize at several positions, sometimes in different combinations ( Fig. 2 ). Especially for labdane-related diterpenoids, the flexibility of CYP 76s is remarkable, because they perform oxidations on eleven different C-positions ( Table 2 ). CYP 725As, somehow, form an exception because this CYP subfamily oxidizes taxane-derivatives at many different positions, although each single member is specific to a certain C-position. The high substrate selectivity of each CYP allows the complex biosynthesis downstream to Taxol
ª
and related taxanes (
).

Regarding the issue of substrate specificity and promiscuity, we note that not all enzymes have been characterized in detail, making it difficult to evaluate how widespread this phenomenon is. Also, in vitro assays or expression in heterologous hosts constitute the basis for labeling enzymes as specific or promiscuous. In their original context however, these enzymes may encounter only a limited number, or even a single, relevant substrates. Thus, enzyme “promiscuity” may not be relevant in planta , but of interest for metabolic engineering applications, for example to generate new-to-nature products.

In summary, on a global scale no clear trend as to the position of oxidation or the type of diterpene backbone used as substrate can be distinguished from the phylogenetic tree in Fig. 2 . One clear trend is the existence of families and sub-families of CYPs, which expanded in specific plant families and are involved in the oxidation of a group of diterpene backbones. In the next sections we will go through these in more detail.

sec.title: 4. The role of cytochrome P450 enzymes in plant specialized diterpenoid metabolism

mixed-citation.named-content: Cytochrome P450 enzymes: A driving force of plant diterpene diversity

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
4.1. The CYP 76 family is a dominant catalyzer of labdane diterpene
diversification in Lamiaceae

tp:treatment-sec.p:
The Lamiaceae include more than 7800 species (www.theplantlist. org) many of which are used as spices or as medicinal plants ( Kokkini et al., 2003 ). Prominent examples are
Rosmarinus officinalis
,
Salvia sp.
or
Coleus forskohlii
which contain compounds of industrial relevance such as carnosic acid, carnosol, sclareol and forskolin, respectively ( Follin-Arbelet et al., 2015 ; Ibarra et al., 2011 ; Johnson, 2011 ). As fragrances, drug components or food additives – metabolites from Lamiaceae species have been of great interest for decades. Labdane-related diterpenoids, which can be found in more than 20 genera ( Vestri Alvarenga et al., 2001 ), contribute significantly to the interest in this plant family. A survey of diterpenes present in Lamiaceae predicted 91 different backbones ( Vestri Alvarenga et al., 2001 ). Knowing that each of these skeletons can be further oxidized at several positions, in different combinations, and that additional modifications such as acylation and glycosylation are possible, it is likely that the number of diterpenoids in Lamiaceae alone is close to or even in excess of 1000. In this structural diversification, CYPs of the CYP 76 family, and to a lesser extent from the CYP 71 family, play a dominant role in the oxidation of diterpenes in the Lamiaceae (
, Table 1 ). The last five years have seen the characterization of CYPs from rosemary, sage species and
C. forskohlii
that participate in the biosynthesis of phenolic diterpenes, related tanshinones and the manoyl oxide derived forskolin, respectively. Most of them belong to the two distinct but closely related subgroups, CYP 76AH and CYP 76AK (
). The former are rather involved in the oxidation of olefinic or alcohol diterpenes. For example, CYP 76AH1 is a ferruginol synthase from
Salvia miltiorrhiza
which has been co-expressed with the required diTPS and cytochrome P450 reductase (SmCPR) in the model organism
Saccharomyces cerevisiae
to reconstruct ferruginol biosynthesis ( Guo et al., 2013 ). This step was proposed to be the first committed step in tanshinone biosynthesis in danshen (
S. miltiorrhiza
).
CYP 76AH1
RNAi lines of hairy root cultures of
S. miltiorrhiza
exhibited accumulation of the precursor miltiradiene in parallel to a reduction of downstream tanshinones proving the role of ferruginol as starting point for further decorations in tanshinone biosynthesis ( Ma et al., 2015 , 2016). Recent studies provided more insights into tanshinone biosynthesis by the characterization of SmCYP76AH3, which oxidizes ferruginol to 11-hydroxy ferruginol. The authors also demonstrated the promiscuity of these CYPs, which can oxidize their substrates at C 7, C 11 and C 12, leading to a spectrum of products ( Guo et al., 2016 ). The final steps in tanshinone biosynthesis have not been clarified so far but presumably require other types of reactions, C-C cleavage and decarboxylation, which may or may not be catalyzed by CYPs. Alternatively, it is conceivable that different enzyme families such as 2-oxoglutarate-dependent dioxygenases (2-ODD) participate in the downstream pathway as it can be inferred from 2-ODD RNAi lines of hairy root cultures which displayed reduced tanshinone content ( Xu and Song, 2017 ).

Species closely related to
S. miltiorrhiza
such as
Salvia fruticosa
,
Salvia pomifera
and
R. officinalis
also produce phenolic diterpenes. There, RoCYP76AH4, RoCYP76AH22-23 and Sf/SpCYP76AH24 are highly similar to SmCYP76AH1, but carry out two successive oxidations on the substrate miltiradiene/abietatriene at two different positions on the C-ring, leading to the synthesis of 11-hydroxy ferruginol (Bo ž i
ć et al., 2015
; Ignea et al., 2016 ; Scheler et al., 2016 ; Zi and Peters, 2013 ). Interestingly, these 11-hydroxy ferruginol synthases accept not only miltiradiene/abietatriene as substrate but also manoyl oxide, pointing to a certain degree of promiscuity of these enzymes not only with regards to the position but also to the diterpene substrate ( Pateraki et al., 2017 ).

Downstream of the hydroxy ferruginol synthases ( CYP 76AHs), four enzymes from
Salvia sp.
and
R. officinalis
of the CYP 76AK subfamily have been identified. They were collectively named C 20 oxidases because they oxidize their substrates at position C 20 ( Guo et al., 2016 ; Ignea et al., 2016 ; Scheler et al., 2016 ). Like CYP 76AHs, CYP 76AKs are promiscuous and therefore form a variety of metabolites. For example, Sf/SpCYP76AK6 and RoCYP76AK7-8 are involved in the biosynthesis of carnosic acid in
R. officinalis
,
S. fruticosa
and
S. pomifera
and catalyze three successive oxidations at C 20 on 11-hydroxy ferruginol to carnosic acid via the alcohol and the aldehyde (carnosaldehyde) as intermediates. Although, C 20 oxidases also have activity on ferruginol, yielding pisiferol, pisiferal and pisiferic acid, we showed that CYP 76AK8 favors 11-hydroxy ferruginol instead of ferruginol ( Scheler et al., 2016 ).

Next to C 20 oxidases from the carnosic acid pathway, there is one characterized C 20 oxidase from
S. miltiorrhiza , SmCYP
76AK1. It shares high sequence similarity with CYP 76AK6-8 (more than 68% on protein level) and is a promiscuous CYP that accepts several substrates and is proposed to be involved in tanshinone biosynthesis. SmCYP76AK1 introduces a single hydroxyl group at position C 20, unlike the C 20 oxidase involved in the biosynthesis of carnosic acid. This results in the production of 11,20-dihydroxy sugiol and 11,20-dihydroxy ferruginol, the latter spontaneously oxidizing to 10-hydroxymethyltetrahydromiltirone ( Guo et al., 2016 ). Spontaneous oxidation has also been shown for other phenolic diterpenes such as carnosic acid to carnosol and 11-hydroxy ferruginol to the corresponding quinone, which is a manifestation of the high antioxidant activities of these compounds ( Loussouarn et al., 2017 ; Scheler et al., 2016 ). It is still not clear whether the in planta conversion of carnosic acid to carnosol occurs via spontaneous oxidation or enzymatically.

Forskolin is a diterpene from
C. forskohlii
which has been long known for its positive effect on glaucoma, as inotrope and because of its vasodilatory activities ( Bristow et al., 1984 ; Caprioli et al., 1984 ; Wysham et al., 1986 ). Its biosynthesis has recently been clarified by Pateraki and co-workers including the characterization of involved CYPs and an acetyl transferase. Interestingly, as in the biosynthesis of carnosic acid, CYPs from the CYP 76AH subfamily, namely CfCYP76AH11 and CfCYP76AH15-16, are involved and catalyze five successive oxidations on manoyl oxide. CfCYP76AH15 was found to have activity on miltiradiene to form ferruginol , while CYP 76AH4 and CYP 76AH22-24 from rosemary and sage accepted manoyl oxide as substrate, providing nice examples of the promiscuity of this enzyme family ( Pateraki et al., 2017 ).

CYPs from the CYP 71 family were until now more known for their activities in mono- and sesquiterpene biosynthesis ( Mau and Croteau, 2006 ). In labdane-related diterpene biosynthesis, only two CYP 71s were found to be involved. CYP 71BE52 from
S. pomifera
and CYP 71D381 from
C. forskohlii
have hydroxylation activity on position C 2 of ferruginol and manoyl oxide, respectively ( Ignea et al., 2016 ). In addition, CfCYP71D381 hydroxylates at position C 19 ( Ignea et al., 2016 ; Pateraki et al., 2017 ). Interestingly, these CYPs share only 49% amino acid sequence similarity but can be collectively considered as C 2 oxidases.

Most recently, CYP 76BK1 from
Vitex agnus-castus
has been reported to oxidize peregrinol, a bicyclic diterpene, at position C 16 to labd-13Z- ene-9,15,16-triol. This compound is presumed to be an intermediate en route to furan- and lactone-containing diterpenoids ( Heskes et al., 2018 ). This constitutes yet another addition of a diterpene CYP to the CYP 76 family from Lamiaceae , further supporting the important role of this CYP family in diterpene diversification in Lamiaceae .

In Arabidopsis CYP 76 enzymes have been shown to be involved in the oxidation of monoterpenes ( Boachon et al., 2015 ; Hofer et al., 2014 ). Also, CYP 76 enzymes exist in Gymnosperms ( Nelson and Werck-Reichhart, 2011 ), and it remains to be seen whether in these species as well they are involved in the biosynthesis of similar compounds, such as pisiferic acid, a ferruginol derived carboxylic acid, from
Chamaecyparis pisifera ( Kobayashi et al., 1987 )
.

sec.title: 4.2. Diterpene phytoalexin metabolism in rice is catalyzed by diverse CYP families that are organized in two distinct biosynthetic gene clusters

mixed-citation.named-content: Cytochrome P450 enzymes: A driving force of plant diterpene diversity

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
4.3. Gene clusters for diterpene metabolism in Euphorbiaceae are conserved
in several species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
The Euphorbiaceae family contains 228 plant genera and around 6500 species (www.theplantlist.org). Some family members are used in traditional medicine in Arabia, China , India and in particular in Africa. They are used to treat inter alia epilepsy, anemia, diarrhea, cancer, fungal infections and oedema ( Chhabra et al., 1990 ). In many cases, bioactivity could be assigned to diterpenoids from these plants ( Beutler et al., 1989 ). They typically have a macrocyclic structure derived from the casbene, rosane, lathyrane, tigliane or ingenane backbones ( Vasas and Hohmann, 2014 ). In addition to ethnomedical knowledge, experimental data demonstrated the significance of Euphorbiaceae diterpenoids for therapeutic applications, including against cancer, HIV latent infection or to treat intractable pain (
Corea et al., 2009
; King et al., 2014 ; Lebwohl et al., 2012 ; Reis et al., 2013 ). The genes currently known to be involved in Euphorbiaceae diterpene biosynthesis share a high degree of conservation and organization, typically in genetic clusters. For example,
Ricinus communis
(castor bean) has a biosynthetic cluster with several genes coding for two casbene synthases (CBSs), one neocembrene synthase, six CYP726As (CYP726A13-18), two SDRs, one BAHD acyltransferase, two CYPs from the CYP80C family and one TPSg terpene synthase likely involved in monoterpene biosynthesis. Similar biosynthetic clusters can be found in
Euphorbia peplus
, revealing genes encoding a CBS and CYP726A19, and on chromosome 1 of
Jatropha curcas
with three CBSs, five CYP726As (CYP726A20, CYP726A21, CYP726A23, CYP726A24 and CYP726A35), two CYPs from the CYP71D subfamily, four alkenal reductases and three monoterpene synthases ( Boutanaev et al., 2015 ; King et al., 2014 , 2016). Remarkably, these genetic clusters occur in species that belong to distinct major sub-families. It was therefore concluded that the production of Euphorbiaceae diterpenoids evolved early in the emergence of this plant family more than 100 million years ago ( King et al., 2014 ). During evolution upstream biosynthetic enzymes providing the diterpene backbones (for example casbene, jatrophane or pepluane) kept a high degree of conservation across species because the different backbone types were found in several species ( Shi et al., 2008 ).

In the pathway of casbene-derived diterpenoids, CYP71 clan subfamily members of CYP726A and CYP71D appear to be the driving force for the production of higher oxidized derivatives (
). Some of them are promiscuous and accept not only casbene but also neocembrene. While CYP726A15 from
R. communis
oxidizes neocembrene at C5, casbene can be oxidized at C5, C6 and C9 by CYP726A14 and CYP726A17-18 from
R. communis
, by CYP726A20, CYP726A35 and CYP71D495 from
J. curcas
, by CYP726A27 and CYP71D445 from
Euphorbia lathyris
, and by CYP726A19, CYP71D365 and CYP726A4 from
E. peplus
( Boutanaev et al., 2015 ; King et al., 2014 ; Luo et al., 2016 ). Due to the large number of existing casbene-5-oxidases, this catalytic activity was concluded to be a key step in the biosynthesis of Euphorbiaceae diterpenoids and provides further evidence of a conserved biosynthetic pathway within this plant family ( King et al., 2014 ). Downstream, an alcohol dehydrogenase from
E. lathyris , ADH
1, was recently found to convert 6-keto-5,9-casbenediol into jolkinol C, although the same reaction on the highly similar 6-hydroxy-5,9-diketocasbene can occur spontaneously ( King et al., 2016 ; Luo et al., 2016 ). The formation of jolkinol C is characterized by a ring-closure, which is also indispensable for jatrophane, ingenane, myrsinane, daphnane, and lathyrane diterpenes. One can therefore assume that it represents a key step in Euphorbiaceae diterpenoid biosynthesis. However, biosynthetic genes of other Euphorbiaceae diterpenes remain unknown, and further research is necessary to elucidate the pathway of more complex Euphorbiaceae metabolites such as resiniferatoxin, ingenol mebutate and prostratin.

sec.title:
4.4. CYP 714s: a crossover between gibberellin and steviol glycoside
biosynthesis

4.5. CYP 720B is a conifer-specific CYP subfamily involved in defense
reactions
sec.p:
The authors grouped these CYP 720Bs in four clades (I to IV) based on functional and phylogenetic criteria. While CYP 720B1 and CYP 720B4 are classified as clade III CYPs because they oxidize diterpene olefins, CYP 720B2 and CYP 720B12 from clade I use 13-hydroxy-8 (14)-abietene as substrate, an unstable product of levopimaradiene/abietadiene synthase. Regardless of the substrate, the final products are the C 18-acids (abietic acid, neoabietic acid, levopimaric acid and palustric acid) by non-enzymatic elimination of water (
). The substrate variability of clade I and III CYPs is presumably part of an ecological strategy to ensure effective defense mechanisms in conifers against herbivory and pathogens ( Fig. 4 ). It is, however, not clear if clade II and IV CYPs contribute to DRA biosynthesis or if they are involved in other biosynthesis pathways.

sec.title: 4.6. Plant taxane biosynthesis is a complex pathway dominated by
sec.p: CYP 725s

mixed-citation.named-content: Cytochrome P450 enzymes: A driving force of plant diterpene diversity

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature: 4.7. Isolated examples of diterpenoids found in Solanaceae species

tp:treatment-sec.p:
In the Solanaceae , only two examples of CYPs acting on diterpenes have been reported so far. Unlike in Lamiaceae , these are not labdane-related diterpenes. In
Nicotiana tabacum
, the trichome-specific CYP71D16 converts the macrocyclic diterpene alcohols α- and β- cembratrien-ol to α- and β- cembratrien-diol, respectively. Silencing of
CYP71D 16
in
N. tabacum
results in accumulation of α- and β- cembratrien-ol and increases resistance against aphids ( Wang et al., 2001 ). NtCYP71D16 is related to CYP71s that are involved in the oxidation of the tobacco sesquiterpene phytoalexin capsidiol ( Ralston et al., 2001 ). It is therefore possible that NtCYP71D16 evolved from this branch of the CYP71 family that was initially involved in the oxidation of sesquiterpenes.

sec.title: 5. Summary and perspectives
sec.p: Some conclusions can be drawn from our analysis. The first is that CYPs involved in plant specialized diterpene biosynthesis belong to a limited set of clans, namely CYP 71 and CYP 72 in Angiosperms and CYP 85 in Gymnosperms. However, beyond these large clans there is no general rule for the assignment of the catalytic function of CYPs in diterpene biosynthesis. This is not surprising, given that plant diterpenoids are specialized metabolites for which structural sub-classes are restricted to certain plant families or even in some cases plant genuses (e.g. taxanes) ( Fig. 2 ). However, some families are associated with specific taxonomic groups (e.g. CYP 76s in Lamiaceae and rice, CYP 725As in Taxus and CYP 726As in Euphorbiaceae ) where they contribute to the metabolic diversity of specific subgroups of diterpenoids. In addition to this clade-specific expansion of sub-families of CYPs, specialized diterpene CYPs were found to derive via gene duplication from hormonal CYPs such as KOs and CYP 714s. In the case of CYP 76, the presence of members involved in specialized diterpene metabolism in rice and Lamiaceae suggests an origin predating the monocot and eudicot separation.

One should note that CYP families covered in this review are not always exclusively involved in diterpene biosynthesis. For example a CYP 88 related to kaurenoic acid oxidases was found to be involved in triterpenoid biosynthesis in licorice (
). We also mentioned earlier CYP 76s from Arabidopsis playing a role in monoterpene oxidation and CYP 71s that are involved in the oxidation of sesqui- or monoterpenes. Interestingly however, these cross-over cases are involved in terpene biosynthesis in general. It would therefore be interesting to extend this study on CYPs to terpenoids in general.

sec.p: The authors declare no conflict of interest.
